messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Robert Watkins

> (Actually, for the ultimate in flexibility, you'd need to
> provide a way to change the runner strategy, too - but that's
> probably overkill)

True, but I didn't see why it shouldn't be possible, so I made sure TestNG
was flexible enough to make that possible. And as a matter of fact, when
TestNG runs in JUnit mode, it uses this API (see IAnnotationFinder, which
lets you pretty much redefine the framework in any way you want).

> Ultimately, what I would like to be able to do is have
> equivalents of popular JUnit extensions, such as DBUnit,
> ServletUnit, and JUnitPerf, which are configured using
> annotations rather than base classes. The annotations
> currently in JUnit 4 wouldn't allow this.
>
> (Cedric, if you're reading this... every one of these points
> applies to TestNG as well)

Right, but I'm still not sure your decorator idea adds anything to the
setUp/tearDown lifecycle that TestNG provides, which are:

- Before/after a suite
- Before/after a test class
- Before/after a test method
- Before/after a test group

Also, I am not sure I understand if your decorators need to implement an
interface or if they are free-form? If the latter, how does the runner
interpret them?

Can you give a concrete example with a real decorator class?
